questions.text: A 54-year-old man with a long-standing history of severe asthma is newly diagnosed with primary open-angle glaucoma. His intraocular pressure is 26 mmHg in both eyes. He is otherwise systemically stable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial topical medication for lowering intraocular pressure in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases aqueous production without respiratory side effects. It is not contraindicated in asthma and thus is the safest among the options listed.
  • Beta-blockers (e.g., carteolol, timolol) are highly effective at lowering IOP but are contraindicated in patients with asthma due to the risk of bronchospasm, bradycardia, and hypotension. Timolol is specifically listed as nonselective and should be avoided in asthmatic individuals. (Option A and B ruled out)
  • Betaxolol, though a selective beta-1 blocker, is mentioned to have fewer pulmonary side effects, but this selectivity is not absolute, and caution is still advised in asthmatic patients. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with normal-tension (low-tension) glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Small optic nerves are not typically associated with normal-tension glaucoma (NTG).
  • Larger optic discs, such as those seen in high myopia, may be more vulnerable to damage at normal or borderline IOP levels.
  • Smaller discs tend to be more resistant to glaucomatous cupping but are instead more prone to other pathologies like non-arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION), not glaucoma

Normal-Tension Glaucoma (NTG):

NTG is a subtype of primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) characterized by progressive optic nerve damage and corresponding visual field loss, despite IOPs consistently ≤21 mm Hg.

Key features:

  • Glaucomatous optic nerve cupping without a history of elevated IOP.
  • Visual field defects that conform to retinal nerve fiber layer loss pattern.
  • Open angles on gonioscopy.
  • No history of secondary causes of raised IOP or other optic neuropathies.
  • Presence of disc hemorrhages (Drance hemorrhages) is common.
  • More common in older patients, particularly females with low blood pressure.

Pathogenesis:

  • Damage may be due to vascular dysregulation rather than elevated IOP.
  • Possible mechanisms include:
    • Nocturnal hypotension
    • Autonomic dysfunction
    • Vascular endothelial dysfunction
    • Impaired blood flow autoregulation

Diagnosis:

Requires:

  • Open anterior chamber angles
  • Consistently normal IOP readings
  • Typical glaucomatous visual field loss
  • Absence of other optic neuropathies or secondary glaucoma

Treatment

  • Targeted IOP lowering, even if IOP is "normal."
  • Pharmacologic therapy (e.g., prostaglandin analogs, brimonidine).
  • Avoidance of nocturnal hypotension (e.g., adjusting antihypertensive timing).
  • Consider laser or surgical options if progression occurs despite low IOP.

Explanation of other options:

Migraine (Option A): Strongly associated with NTG. Patients with migraine may have systemic vascular dysregulation and are more likely to show glaucomatous damage even at normal IOPs due to impaired blood flow autoregulation.

Systemic vascular disease (Option C): Conditions like nocturnal hypotension, vasospasm, and autonomic dysfunction play a major role in NTG pathogenesis by compromising optic nerve perfusion, especially during sleep.

Disc (Drance) hemorrhages (Option D): A classic clinical finding in NTG, these small, flame-shaped hemorrhages at the optic disc margin are signs of ongoing glaucomatous damage and are more common in NTG than in high-pressure glaucoma.

questions.text: A patient presents 2 years after glaucoma filtering surgery with purulent discharge and endophthalmitis. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A late bleb-associated endophthalmitis tends to be caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) or Haemophilus influenzae. Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis are more commonly associated with early-onset endophthalmitis after cataract surgery. Propionibacterium acnes has been associated with a later-onset endophthalmitis after cataract surgery. Pseudomonas aeruginosa causes a fulminant endophthalmitis but is not frequently reported as a causative agent of late bleb-associated endophthalmitis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has been designated by the FDA to be safest during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Brimonidine is the only antiglaucoma medication classified as FDA Pregnancy Category B.
  • All others-including timolol, dorzolamide, and latanoprost-are Category C. (Options B, C & D ruled out)
  • Data on safety is limited; most evidence comes from animal studies or isolated case reports.
  • When treatment is necessary, brimonidine is preferred due to its relatively better safety profile.
  • Patients should be advised to use nasolacrimal occlusion to reduce systemic absorption.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6219332/

It can develop in a patient with a wide angle

questions.text: Which statement best describes primary angle-closure glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary angle-closure glaucoma is typically triggered by darkness due to pupil dilation, which increases iridolenticular contact and precipitates angle closure in anatomically predisposed eyes.

Primary Angle-Closure Glaucoma (PACG):

A group of glaucomas characterized by elevated intraocular pressure as a result of mechanical obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by either apposition of the peripheral iris to the trabecular meshwork or by synechial angle closure.

Clinical Presentation:

  • May be acute, subacute, or chronic.
  • Acute symptoms: Sudden pain, blurred vision, photophobia, colored halos, headache, nausea, vomiting.
  • Subacute: May mimic migraines or be asymptomatic.
  • Chronic: Often asymptomatic.

Risk Factors:

  1. Demographic
    • Age >60 years
    • Female sex
    • Asian descent
    • Family history (due to inherited ocular anatomy)
  2. Anatomic
    • Shallow anterior chamber
    • Thick, anteriorly positioned lens
    • Short axial length
    • Small corneal diameter
    • Increased iris thickness or curvature
  3. Precipitating Triggers
    • Dim illumination
    • Drugs (e.g., anticholinergics, adrenergics)

Mechanisms:

  • Pupillary Block: Aqueous flow is blocked at the pupil due to iridolenticular contact, causing iris bowing and angle closure. Laser iridotomy relieves the block by restoring flow.
  • Angle Crowding (Non-pupillary block): A thick peripheral iris occludes the angle, especially during dilation, even after iridotomy.
  • Plateau Iris: Anteriorly positioned ciliary processes push the peripheral iris into the angle; persists post-iridotomy (plateau iris syndrome).
  • Aqueous Misdirection (Malignant Glaucoma): Aqueous is misdirected posteriorly, shifting the lens-iris diaphragm forward. Managed with cycloplegics, IOP-lowering meds, or laser/surgery.

Diagnosis:

  1. Clinical Exam
    • Red eye, corneal edema, mid-dilated nonreactive pupil, high IOP (>40 mmHg)
    • Iris whorling, lens glaukomflecken
  2. Slit Lamp Exam
    • Shallow anterior chamber, hazy cornea
    • Use of the Van Herick method or limbal chamber depth for angle estimation
  3. Gonioscopy
    • Gold standard to assess the angle and presence of PAS
    • Use Shaffer, Scheie, or Spaeth grading systems
  4. Imaging
    • UBM: Visualizes anterior segment and underlying mechanisms (e.g., plateau iris)
    • AS-OCT: Non-contact, fast imaging of angle and anterior chamber

Management:

Acute PACG (Emergency)

  1. Initial Medical Treatment:
    • Topical β-blockers, α2-agonists, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
    • Pilocarpine (only if IOP <50 mmHg)
    • Oral/IV acetazolamide or hyperosmotic agents
    • Topical corticosteroids
  2. Definitive Treatment:
    • Laser Iridotomy (preferred)
    • Laser Iridoplasty if corneal edema prevents iridotomy
    • Anterior chamber paracentesis if refractory
  3. Surgical Options:
    • Lens extraction (if lens is the culprit)
    • Surgical peripheral iridectomy
    • Trabeculectomy or drainage implants in refractory cases

Chronic PACG

  • Treated with long-term medications (e.g., prostaglandin analogues)
  • Laser or surgical intervention if IOP remains uncontrolled
  • Goniosynechialysis during cataract surgery in cases with PAS

Explanation of other options:

It is commonly associated with myopia (Option A): Incorrect. PACG is more commonly associated with hyperopia, which is linked to short axial length and shallow anterior chamber depth. Myopic eyes typically have longer axial lengths and deeper anterior chambers, making angle closure less likely.

It often causes no pain (Option B): Incorrect. Acute PACG typically causes severe ocular pain, headache, nausea, vomiting, and blurred vision. However, chronic forms may be asymptomatic, which makes this statement partially true but misleading in the context of typical presentations.

It can develop in a patient with a wide angle (Option C): Incorrect. By definition, PACG involves anatomically narrow angles. While mechanisms like plateau iris or lens-induced angle crowding can cause angle closure even in eyes that initially appear open, truly wide-angle anatomy does not lead to PACG.

questions.text: Which syndrome is associated with target sign?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome:

  1. Characteristics:
    • PXS is characterized by the deposition of a fibrillar material.
    • This material accumulates in the anterior segment of the eye.
  2. Material Source:
    • The exact origin of this material is not precisely known.
    • It is believed to arise from multiple sources.
    • It is part of a generalized basement membrane disorder.
  3. Effects on Zonules:
    • The deposition of pseudoexfoliation material on the lens zonules can lead to zonular weakness.
  • Pigment Dispersion Syndrome(Option A):This eye condition involves the release of pigment from the iris, leading to pigment accumulation in the eye and potential complications like glaucoma.
  • UGH Syndrome (Uveitis-Glaucoma-Hyphema Syndrome) (Option C):UGH syndrome is characterized by inflammation in the eye (uveitis), elevated intraocular pressure (glaucoma), and bleeding in the anterior chamber (hyphema), often associated with intraocular lens implants.
  • Sturge-Weber Syndrome(Option D):A rare neurological disorder, it features facial port-wine birthmarks and can involve eye issues, including glaucoma, due to abnormal blood vessel development in the brain and eye.

The above given syndromes have an open angle, and narrowing of the anterior chamber angle is not typically observed in these syndromes.

questions.text: Which ocular disease is generally characterized by normal intraocular pressure interrupted by recurrent episodes of markedly elevated intraocular pressure associated with low-grade anterior chamber inflammation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glaucomatocyclitic crisis is a unilateral condition characterized by episodic, marked elevation of intraocular pressure (IOP) (typically 40-60 mmHg) alongside mild anterior uveitis, with attacks usually lasting 1-3 weeks.

Between episodes, IOP normalizes, the eye appears quiet, and the angle remains open without synechiae, although recurrent episodes may lead to glaucomatous optic neuropathy.

Features:

  • Episodic, unilateral, markedly elevated IOP (40-60 mmHg).
  • Mild anterior uveitis during attacks.
  • No posterior synechiae or peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS).
  • Open angles on gonioscopy.
  • Attacks last a few hours to a month, commonly 1-3 weeks.
  • No signs of inflammation or glaucoma between episodes; the fellow eye remains unaffected.
  • Etiology uncertain; possible infectious link (e.g., CMV, HSV, pylori).

Management:

  • IOP-lowering agents (e.g., apraclonidine, brimonidine, aqueous suppressants; prostaglandins are less studied).
  • Topical corticosteroids/NSAIDs may be used, though they don't shorten or prevent attacks.
  • Consider aqueous PCR if infectious etiology is suspected; valganciclovir for CMV (requires toxicity monitoring).

Explanation of other options:

Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis (Option A): Presents with chronic low-grade uveitis, iris atrophy, and heterochromia, but lacks the episodic marked IOP spikes seen in glaucomatocyclitic crisis.

Pseudoexfoliation glaucoma (Option C): A chronic form of secondary open-angle glaucoma with deposition of fibrillary material, usually bilateral and not associated with recurrent inflammation.

Pigmentary glaucoma (Option D): Involves chronic pigment dispersion with variable IOP, commonly bilateral, and not typically associated with anterior uveitis or sudden IOP surges.

questions.text: Which class of glaucoma medications should be avoided in a patient with a sulfa allergy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs), including oral agents like acetazolamide and methazolamide, and topical agents like dorzolamide and brinzolamide, are structurally related to sulfonamides.
  • Although the sulfonamide group, most commonly responsible for allergic reactions, is not present in dorzolamide, caution is still advised in patients with a sulfa allergy, as adverse effects may still occur.
  • Topical CAIs are generally well tolerated, but a small allergic rate (~10%) is noted.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Prostaglandin Analogues (Option B): These drugs (e.g., latanoprost, travoprost) increase uveoscleral outflow to lower IOP. They are not chemically related to sulfonamides and are not associated with cross-reactivity in sulfa-allergic patients.

Miotics (Option C): Miotics like pilocarpine increase aqueous outflow by contracting the ciliary muscle. They have no structural relation to sulfonamide compounds and are safe for sulfa-allergic individuals.

Beta Blockers (Option D): Agents such as timolol and betaxolol reduce aqueous production by blocking beta receptors in the ciliary epithelium. These drugs are not sulfonamide derivatives and do not pose cross-reactivity risks in patients with sulfa allergy.

choices.text: Asymmetric appearance of the optic disc or rim between the two eyes
Diffuse or focal narrowing of the disc rim, especially at the inferior and superior poles

questions.text: What abnormality of the optic disc rim is not specific for early glaucomatous damage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Optic disc rim pallor is not specific for glaucoma
  • Pallor indicates optic atrophy, which can result from diverse causes like inflammation, ischemia, compression, nutritional deficiencies, toxins, trauma, or hereditary conditions.
  • In glaucoma, the hallmark change is neuroretinal rim thinning/cupping, not pallor; true pallor-especially in excess of cupping-usually points to nonglaucomatous optic neuropathy

Differential Diagnoses of Optic Disc Rim Pallor

  1. Ischemic Optic Neuropathy
    • Sudden vision loss, usually in older adults
    • Pale, swollen disc acutely → pallor in chronic phase
  2. Compressive Optic Neuropathy
    • Caused by tumors (e.g., meningioma, pituitary adenoma), aneurysms
    • Gradual vision loss; often central or color vision is affected early
  3. Hereditary Optic Neuropathies
    • e.g., Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy (LHON)
    • Bilateral symmetrical pallor, often temporal; young males are commonly affected
  4. Toxic and Nutritional Optic Neuropathy
    • Caused by alcohol, tobacco, methanol, or vitamin B12 deficiency
    • Central scotoma and bilateral temporal pallor are typical
  5. Traumatic Optic Neuropathy
    • Occurs after head or orbital trauma
    • May present with pallor days to weeks after injury
  6. Inflammatory/Autoimmune Optic Neuritis
    • Common in multiple sclerosis
    • Painful vision loss, especially with eye movement; the optic disc may become pale over time

Explanation of other options:

Asymmetric optic disc appearance between the two eyes (Option B): A difference in cup-to-disc ratio greater than 0.2 is rare in normal individuals and often indicates glaucomatous nerve damage.

Diffuse or focal rim narrowing at the inferior and superior poles (Option C): Early glaucoma typically affects the neuroretinal rim in these regions, violating the ISNT rule (Inferior > Superior > Nasal > Temporal).

Optic disc hemorrhage (Drance hemorrhage) (Option D): These are recognized markers of active glaucomatous damage, especially in normal-tension glaucoma, and indicate disease progression.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5365044/

questions.text: During an automated static perimetry, a patient responds when no stimulus is presented. What type of error is this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Automated static perimetry determines the threshold sensitivities at multiple points in the visual field. When a patient responds at a time when no test stimulus is presented, a false positive error is recorded. When a patient fails to respond to a stimulus presented in a location where a dimmer stimulus was previously seen, a false negative response is recorded. Fixation losses are identified when the patient fails to look at the central fixation light during testing. Short-term fluctuation is a measure of normal physiologic variation and intra test reliability, and it is measured when the visual field analyzer double-determines 10 preselected points during the course of the test session.

questions.text: The nerve fiber layer is best visualized at the slit lamp using what special technique?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) is best seen with red-free (green) light, which enhances the contrast of the fine striations created by retinal ganglion cell axons.
  • It helps detect focal wedge-shaped defects or diffuse thinning, which are important early signs of glaucoma.
  • Using red-free light with 6× or 10× magnification allows for optimal visualization of these subtle changes
  • Red-free light improves visibility by filtering out red wavelengths, making the RNFL stand out more clearly against the background retina.

Explanation of other options:

Specular reflection (Option B): Used primarily to examine the posterior surface of the cornea, especially the corneal endothelium. Not useful for viewing the nerve fiber layer or posterior segment.

Fluorescein angiography (Option C): Highlights retinal and choroidal vasculature, especially for diagnosing vascular or neovascular conditions. It does not enhance RNFL visibility.

Cobalt blue illumination (Option D): Used in conjunction with fluorescein dye for evaluating corneal abrasions, tear film, or tonometry readings. Not suitable for imaging the RNFL.

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to cause secondary angle-closure glaucoma secondary to congestion of the ciliary body and ciliochoroidal detachment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Topiramate, a sulfa-derived anticonvulsant used for seizures, migraines, and neuropathic pain, is known to cause bilateral secondary angle-closure glaucoma via ciliochoroidal effusion and forward rotation of the lens-iris diaphragm.

This mechanism mimics primary angle-closure glaucoma but is not caused by pupillary block, making treatments like laser peripheral iridotomy (LPI) ineffective.

Key clinical findings:

  • Rapid onset of bilateral angle closure
  • Markedly elevated IOP (often >60 mmHg)
  • Anterior chamber shallowing and myopic shift
  • Mid-dilated pupils, often reactive (unlike typical pupillary block)
  • Poor response to standard angle-closure therapy (e.g., pilocarpine, LPI)

Diagnosis:

  • Strong suspicion if bilateral angle closure develops within days to weeks of starting topiramate
  • Confirmed by clinical exam and B-scan (which may or may not show ciliochoroidal effusion)

Management:

  • Immediate discontinuation of topiramate
  • Use of cycloplegics and topical corticosteroids
  • Avoid miotics like pilocarpine (which worsen the condition)
  • IOP-lowering agents as needed (beta blockers, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, hyperosmotics)

Explanation of other options:

Azithromycin (Option A): A macrolide antibiotic; no known association with secondary angle closure or ciliochoroidal detachment.

Acetaminophen (Option B): Common analgesic and antipyretic; not linked to glaucoma-related complications.

Valium (Diazepam) (Option C): A benzodiazepine used for anxiety and seizures; does not cause angle-closure glaucoma.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2687928/

questions.text: One week after a trabeculectomy, a patient has a flat peripheral anterior chamber with iris to cornea touch, but no lens to cornea touch, applanation tension near 0 mm Hg, large choroidal effusions, and a positive Seidel test with a flat bleb. What would the single most important step be at this time?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this post-trabeculectomy scenario, the most critical issue is the bleb leak, indicated by:

  • Positive Seidel test
  • Flat bleb
  • Shallow anterior chamber
  • Low intraocular pressure (IOP ~0 mmHg)
  • Choroidal effusions

All of these findings point to hypotony due to excessive aqueous outflow via the leaking bleb.

Closing the leak is the priority because:

  • The leak is the primary cause of hypotony and associated complications (shallow AC, choroidal effusions).
  • Without closing the leak, reforming the anterior chamber or draining the effusions will not resolve the underlying issue.
  • Persistent hypotony can lead to vision-threatening complications like hypotony maculopathy or suprachoroidal hemorrhage.

Management Strategy:

  • If mild: Conservative measures such as pressure patching, bandage contact lens, or aqueous suppressants
  • If severe (as in this case), Surgical intervention is needed to close the leak and restore IOP.

Explanation of other options:

Reform the anterior chamber (Option B): This is secondary and may not be necessary if there's no lens-cornea touch.

Increase corticosteroids (Option C): Steroids treat inflammation but won't address the hypotony from the bleb leak.

Drain choroidal effusions (Option D): Effusions are secondary to low IOP; draining them without fixing the leak risks worsening hypotony.

choices.text: Amount of glaucomatous optic nerve cupping
Amount of glaucomatous visual field loss

questions.text: In an eye with a narrow angle, which of the following most strongly argues in favor of performing a laser peripheral iridotomy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gonioscopy is the most critical tool for diagnosing and managing angle-closure disease.
  • In cases of chronic primary angle-closure (PAC) and angle-closure suspect (ACS) with relative pupillary block, gonioscopic evidence of appositional angle closure or the presence of peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) strongly supports the need for a laser peripheral iridotomy (LPI). These findings directly confirm the anatomical basis of angle closure and guide intervention.
  • LPI is best done before irreversible damage occurs, and gonioscopy identifies the risk early, even if IOP and optic nerve are normal.
  • Iridotomy is indicated in:
  • Angle closure
  • Angle closure glaucoma
  • Angle closure suspect, especially if:
    • Angle closure in the fellow eye
    • Family history of Angle closure glaucoma
    • Need for repeated dilated examinations
    • Poor access to regular ophthalmic care

Explanation of other options:

Intraocular pressure level (Option A): While IOP may be elevated in angle-closure disease, high IOP alone is not a definitive indication for iridotomy. The angle might be open despite raised pressure, for example, in primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) with coincident narrow angles. Thus, IOP must be interpreted alongside gonioscopic findings.

Amount of glaucomatous optic nerve cupping (Option B): Optic nerve cupping indicates the extent of glaucomatous damage but does not determine the mechanism (open vs. angle closure). Cupping can be present in various types of glaucoma and does not specifically mandate iridotomy.

Amount of glaucomatous visual field loss (Option C): Similar to optic nerve cupping, field loss reflects disease severity, not etiology. LPI is targeted to correct the mechanism(e.g., pupillary block), not the damage that has already occurred.

choices.text: A patient with a previous unsuccessful glaucoma filtering surgery
A patient with traumatic glaucoma with angle recession

questions.text: In which one of the following situations would intraoperative mitomycin C application during trabeculectomy be most clearly indicated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mitomycin C (MMC) is an antimetabolite used during trabeculectomy to reduce postoperative scarring by inhibiting fibroblast proliferation at the surgical site. Scarring is a major cause of surgical failure, especially in patients at high risk for fibrosis.

  • Patients with previous failed glaucoma filtering surgery are at high risk of scarring due to already activated fibroblastic response from the first surgery.
  • MMC significantly reduces the risk of trabeculectomy failure in such high-risk cases.
  • MMC inhibits subconjunctival fibrosis, helping maintain bleb patency and long-term IOP control.

Explanation of Other Options:

A 25-year-old patient (Option B): Younger patients heal more aggressively and may form more scar tissue. However, the use of MMC in young patients must be cautious due to the increased risk of hypotony and long-term complications. MMC is not absolutely contraindicated, but less clearly indicated unless other high-risk factors are present.

A patient with traumatic glaucoma with angle recession (Option C): This is not typically associated with excessive conjunctival scarring. The pathology is in the angle, not in the conjunctiva. MMC use here is not strongly indicated unless there are additional risk factors like inflammation or prior surgery.

A Black patient (Option D): Black patients have a higher risk of scarring, but race alone is not a sufficient reason to strongly indicate MMC. Clinical judgment is needed; 5-FU may be preferred due to a more favorable safety profile in some cases.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8406713/

choices.text: An eye with angle recession and phacodonesis after blunt trauma

questions.text: Which of the following glaucomas might not resolve after cataract extraction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Angle recession is a tear between the circular and longitudinal muscles of the ciliary body due to blunt trauma.
  • It damages the trabecular meshwork, leading to chronic open-angle glaucoma.
  • Phacodonesis indicates zonular weakness, but in this case, the lens is not the main cause of the intraocular pressure (IOP) elevation.
  • Since the underlying pathology is structural damage to the angle, cataract surgery will not correct the mechanism of glaucoma in such eyes.

Explanation of other options:

Primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG) (Option A): Often due to pupillary block from a relatively anterior lens in a short axial length eye. Cataract extraction deepens the anterior chamber, relieves pupillary block, and can improve or eliminate glaucoma. May resolve after cataract surgery.

Microspherophakia with glaucoma (Option B): The small, spherical lens leads to pupillary block and secondary angle-closure glaucoma. Cataract removal or lensectomy relieves the block and controls IOP. May resolve after lens removal.

Phacolytic glaucoma (Option C): Caused by leakage of high-molecular-weight lens proteins from a hypermature cataract. These proteins block the trabecular meshwork, raising IOP. Cataract extraction removes the source of obstruction. Typically resolves with cataract surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following risk factors is probably the least significant for primary open-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Although glaucoma is not equated with elevated intraocular pressure, intraocular pressure is probably the most important risk factor for visual loss. Family history and racial or ethnic background are also highly important risk factors. There is mounting evidence for the genetic basis of many of the glaucomas. Other factors, such as myopia and diabetes mellitus, are probably less important risk factors for primary open-angle glaucoma.

choices.text: Topical miotic (cholinergic) therapy (pilocarpine, carbachol, echothiophate iodide)
Beta-adrenergic antagonist (betaxolol, carteolol, levobunolol, metipranolol, timolol)
Topical or oral carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide, methazolamide, dichlorphenamide, dorzolamide)

questions.text: In an eye with increased episcleral venous pressure, which of the following medical agents would be expected to have the least intraocular pressure-lowering effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pilocarpine is a miotic (cholinergic agonist) that lowers intraocular pressure by increasing trabecular outflow.
  • In increased episcleral venous pressure (EVP), trabecular outflow is already compromised due to back-pressure from elevated venous pressure. Hence, pilocarpine is ineffective.

Glaucoma with elevated episcleral venous pressure:

Glaucoma caused by decreased aqueous outflow secondary to elevated episcleral venous pressure (EVP).

Pathophysiology

  • Elevated EVP increases IOP by obstructing the normal drainage of aqueous humor via the trabecular outflow.
  • Goldmann Equation: IOP = (F/C) + EVP where F = aqueous production, C = outflow facility
  • Trabecular outflow is ineffective in these cases, so miotics (e.g., pilocarpine) and laser trabeculoplasty are less useful.

Ocular Features

  • Unilateral elevated IOP
  • Tortuous/engorged episcleral veins
  • Blood in Schlemm's canal
  • Proptosis, eye misalignment, resistance to retropulsion, chemosis
  • Rare: iris neovascularization, hemorrhagic choroidal detachment

Venous and arterial abnormalities leading to elevated EVP:

  • Superior vena cava syndrome
  • Thyroid ophthalmopathy
  • Sturge-Weber syndrome
  • Jugular vein obstruction/thrombosis
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • Dural-cavernous fistula
  • Carotid-cavernous fistula
  • Orbital varix

Medical Management

  • Best first-line agents:
    • Beta-blockers (e.g., betaxolol)
    • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide)
    • Alpha-agonists (vasoconstrictive effect)
    • Prostaglandin analogs (↑ uveoscleral outflow)
  • Ineffective agents:
    • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine) -act on the trabecular outflow, which is already compromised
  • Laser trabeculoplasty is not useful
  • Surgery (e.g., tube shunts, trabeculectomy) may be needed
  • Sturge-Weber patients: High risk of suprachoroidal hemorrhage

Explanation of other options:

Betaxolol (Option B)(Beta-blocker):

  • Mechanism: Decreases aqueous humor production by blocking β-adrenergic receptors in the ciliary epithelium.
  • Pathway unaffected by EVP: It does not depend on outflow pathways, so it's still effective.
  • Betaxolol is cardioselective and safer in patients with respiratory conditions.

Acetazolamide (Option C) (Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitor):

  • Mechanism: Inhibits carbonic anhydrase enzyme in the ciliary body → Reduces aqueous humor formation.
  • Independent of outflow: Like beta-blockers, it works by reducing production, so it's effective despite elevated EVP.

Latanoprost (Option D)(Prostaglandin Analog):

  • Mechanism: Increases uveoscleral outflow (an alternative pathway not significantly affected by EVP).
  • Advantage: Bypasses the trabecular meshwork and Schlemm's canal.
  • Highly effective in most types of glaucoma, including cases with high EVP.

questions.text: The above image measures what area of the visual field?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shown is of a Bjerrum's Screen, also known as a tangent screen.
  • It is used for manual perimetry to assess the central 30° of the visual field.
  • This area is crucial for detecting early glaucomatous field defects, such as paracentral scotomas and arcuate defects.

questions.text: SITA stands for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • SITA stands for Swedish Interactive Threshold Algorithm.
  • It is a modern threshold strategy used in automated perimetry, especially in Humphrey Visual Field Analyzers.
  • SITA improves testing by:
    • Reducing test time
    • Maintaining accuracy
    • Adapting in real-time based on patient responses
  • Common modes include SITA Standard and SITA Fast, used for glaucoma diagnosis and monitoring.
